Let\[ f(\theta) = \sum_{0\leq k\leq n}c_k e^{ik\theta}\]be a trigonometric polynomial all of whose roots are real, such that $\max_{\theta\in [0,2\pi]}\lvert f(\theta)\rvert=1$. Then\[\int_0^{2\pi}\lvert f(\theta)\rvert \mathrm{d}\theta \leq 4.\]



This is Problem 4.20 in \cite{Ha74}, where it is attributed to Erd\H{o}s.

This was solved independently by Kristiansen \cite{Kr74} (only in the case when $c_k\in\mathbb{R}$) and Saff and Sheil-Small \cite{SSS73} (for general $c_k\in \mathbb{C}$).




References


[Ha74] Hayman, W. K., Research problems in function theory: new problems. (1974), 155--180.

[Kr74] Kristiansen, G. K., Proof of an inequality for trigonometric polynomials. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. (1974), 49-57.

[SSS73] No reference found.
